STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 19, 2021
Danielle Martin
Kalamazoo County DHHS
427 E Alcott Street
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
RE: License #: CP390201215
Kalamazoo County DHHS
427 E Alcott Street
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
Dear Ms. Martin:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
11/8/2021-11/18/2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
policy and MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your
policy. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP390201215
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Kalamazoo County DHHS
Facility Address: 427 E Alcott Street
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
Facility Telephone #: (269) 337-5000
Original Issuance Date: 09/10/1993
Service Types: Certify Homes for Foster Care Licensure
Receive Children for Placement in Foster
Care
Supervise Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 11/8/2021-11/18/2021
Total No. Of Records No. of Records
Reviewed

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

since last inspection 0 0

since the last inspection 74 8
No. of children whose sibling groups were split 46 2
No. of children who have had 3 or more placements 76 4
No. of children with unlicensed relatives 40 2

since the last inspection 2 2

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
The agency has been unable to maintain caseload compliance during the period
under review due to a 44% staff vacancy.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
3 of 8 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation of a gap from the
time CPR/First Aid training expired until it was renewed.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible, the time
frames for correction; methods for ensuring the safety of any
children placed in the home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved; consequences if the
corrective action plan is not completed; and what documentation
will be required to demonstrate compliance or completion.
(ii) Require that the corrective action be completed within
six (6) months of being signed.
4

(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the
agency.
1 of 8 open foster family files reviewed contained an annual evaluation that stated
the family was in full compliance despite also documenting that the family was not
practicing emergency procedures as required. No CAP was developed to address
the rule violation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical authority
which indicates that immunizations are current or
contraindicated is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the department of
community health signed by the parent stating immunizations
are not being administered due to religious, medical, or other
reasons is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations shall begin within 30
calendar days of placement.
1 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed contained documentation
that the youth was overdue for multiple immunization which was not addressed
within 30 days.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
FOM 801-01 required a greater frequency stated as:
A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every six
months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
5

1 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed contained a periodic dental
exam completed at a 9-month interval.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days after the initial removal from the
home.
2 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed contained Initial Service
Plans completed outside of the required timeframe by 1 and 2 days, respectively.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed contained Updated Service
Plans completed outside of the requirement. One was completed 9 days late and 3
others were overdue by 2 days, 7 days, and 2 months respectively and remained “in
progress” at the time of this inspection.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 722-03E PLACEMENT EXCEPTION REQUESTS AND APPROVALS
Caseworkers must complete a placement exception request
(PER) when there is a need to waive placement standards to
maintain sibling and caregiver bonds or to meet the medical,
emotional, and psychological needs of children in care. PERs
must be completed, reviewed, and approved in MiSACWIS.
6

When verbal approval for a PER has been given prior to
placement, documentation and approval within MiSACWIS must
be completed within 30 calendar days from the date of the
verbal approval.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained a PER for a sibling split that
has remained pending past 30 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
P. 5 & 11
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there is more than
one caregiver, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with each child in the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement change.
CHILD IN A PARENTAL PLACEMENT
The contact standards detailed in this section are required
anytime a child is placed with their parent or legal guardian.
Residential or Institutional Setting
When a child is placed in a residential or institutional setting, the
caseworker must have contact with the case manager/therapist
assigned to the child, as described in this section.
MiSACWIS Documentation
Caseworkers must identify whether a private meeting, or safe
sleep verification for infants, occurred for each child participant
in the Participant screen within the Social Work Contact section
of MiSACWIS.
7

7 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed were missing either 2 face
to face contacts with the youth within first 2 months of replacement, documentation
that the second caregiver was present quarterly, documentation that visits took place
in the placement home with caregiver, or documentation that contact with the
required caregiver during CCI visit took place. Additionally, quality visit standards
were not documented in all of the visits that were documented.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
FOM 722-06J RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IN FOSTER CARE
Within 30 calendar days of removal, the caseworker must review
and explain the DHS-5307, Rights and Responsibilities for
Children and Youth in Foster Care, and the agency's grievance
policy with the child, foster parents, caregivers, and parents. The
caseworker must be prepared to answer any questions the child,
parents, and caregivers may have.
After the document is reviewed the signatures of the child and
caseworker must be obtained. The parent or caregiver must sign
on behalf of the child, if the child is younger than 11 years old or is
unable to sign the document. The caseworker must complete the
information on the last page of the document with the applicable
contact information and provide all participants with a signed copy
and upload a copy to MiSACWIS.
Placement Change When a child under age 11 or who is
otherwise unable to sign the DHS-5307 changes placement, the
caseworker must review the DHS-5307 and the agency's
grievance policy with the new caregiver and obtain their
signature on the DHS-5307 within 30 days of the placement
change.
Documentation The DHS-5307 must be reviewed and re-
signed annually. The caseworker must document the review in
the social work contacts, and the caseworker must upload the
DHS-5307 to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS.
2 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed did not have annually
completed DHHS-5307 present.
FOM 722-08 ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
SUPERVISOR APPROVAL
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
8

1 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed contained an ISP that was
not approved in the required timeframe.
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
P. 30
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
2 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files contained Updated Service Plans that
were not approved within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-09)
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
P. 9 & 10
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check
yes or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
9

The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
9 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed did not contain all of the
required signatures obtained within the required timeframe. The late and/or missing
signatures included parents, caregivers, youth, worker, and/or supervisor.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as ISEP 6.19 & 722-08C)
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
P. 1
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
1 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files reviewed contained an action
summary that was not competed within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-03C)
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
10

For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
7 of 10 (8 foster care and 2 IL) open case files were missing initial, re-placement,
and/or quarterly updated medical passports.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
P. 5 & 12 & 16
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan
(ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
11

Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later than
three business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days
of the FTM.
8 of 10 (8 fc and 2 IL) open case files reviewed were missing either FTMs required
for service plan development and/or placement change within the required
timeframe or the required DHHS-1105 forms for FTMs documented to have been
held.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/18/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 9/10/2020
8/27/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 9/13/19
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Medical Passports must be uploaded to the correct hyperlink.
 1105's and 3307's must be uploaded according to the timeframes identified in
policy.
 FTM's must be entered into the system as indicated by policy.
 Documents must be reviewed prior to upload to ensure that the correct version
with the correct and complete information & signatures is being uploaded.
 HLO must be notified timely of dental appointments to ensure they are
documented in MiSACWIS, as required.
 Action Summaries must be completed within 3 days of program closure, which is
the date the program is closed in MiSACWIS.
 Dentals should be occurring every 6 months until and unless policy is changed to
reflect a "grace period" of additional time to complete the dental exam.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
12

 If the use of IL packets created by the agency are an expectation, they should be
utilized consistently. These packets capture all of the rule requirements of
documenting monthly IL contract compliance.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
This CAP was related to the 2020 Licensing Renewal Inspection Report dated
8/18/2020 for which was CAP was approved 9/10/2020. The agency is not in
compliance with that CAP as this inspection identified 11 areas of repeat non-
compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator identified areas of concern mainly related to high staff
turnover and low staffing. The non-compliances identified in the Chief Administrator
reports were consistent with the findings of the interim licensing inspection which
indicates an awareness of the agency’s functioning by the individual completing the
chief administrator report. It is noted that the agency is currently undergoing a change
in Director/Chief Administrator.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed all reported being overwhelmed by high caseloads which has
resulted in their inability to keep up with all of the paperwork requirement. They all
reported that they are able to maintain regular and frequent contact with the families
on their caseloads and feel they are providing good quality service despite the
inability to complete all required paperwork. The staff all report feeling helped and
supported by their superiors and communicated positive morale.
VII. DCWL Analyst Concerns
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on
a regular license.
November 18, 2021
________________________________________
13

Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 19, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
